Entering the gate here, one knows the elixir of immortality is not found beyond the seas. The elixir of sagehood resides within the human realm. Casting this mirror to reflect others, every detail becomes visible—easily seen and easily known.

Prenatal *qi* and postnatal *qi*—those who attain them are ever as if intoxicated. Prenatal *qi* lies concealed within postnatal *qi*, the true essence of dragon and tiger, most void, most nonbeing, most numinous, most wondrous. Obtaining these two *qi* is called "obtaining the ingredient." When the ingredient is obtained, there are signs: a drowsy, drunken state, with beauty within and harmony suffusing the four limbs, melting like spring.

This occurs daily, not just once. The sun has its conjunctions, the moon has its conjunctions; exhaust *wu* and *ji*, stabilize *geng* and *jia*. As the *Classic* says: *"The moon has no light but borrows the sun’s."* The *Canticle* states: *"Between the dark and new moons, the tally moves within—this is the sun and moon of heaven."* The human body also has its sun and moon, their waxing and waning no different from heaven’s. Know that they too have their conjunctions.

The sun and moon endure by virtue of heaven, their light unceasing; the four seasons transform and endure, mutually grinding and stirring to remain ever new. Those who study the Dao should emulate this. *Wu*-earth is essence, *ji*-earth is true nature. When emotion aligns with nature, metal and wood unite—this principle is inexhaustible; one must fathom its depths. *Geng*-metal and *jia*-wood must first have their positions fixed. *Jia*-wood is the Azure Dragon, *geng*-metal the White Tiger; Heart-Fire is the Vermilion Bird, Kidney-Water the Dark Warrior. The four symbols array the four directions, with earth at the center. The elixir is formed from the *qi* of the five phases. Know that in the eastern position, the dragon emerges from fire; in the western position, the tiger is born of water. The meaning of metal and water sharing a palace, wood and fire as companions, is fully expressed here.

Ascend the Magpie Bridge above, descend the Magpie Bridge below; heaven responds to the stars, earth responds to the tides. The magpies form a bridge across the void, the meeting place of the Cowherd and Weaver Girl. The Dao unites yin and yang, just as the Cowherd and Weaver Girl—without this bridge, they would remain forever apart. The upper Magpie Bridge is the ladder of heaven; the lower Magpie Bridge is the raft of the river. The upper bridge is the operation of the Dipper and Pole Star, aligning yin and yang, corresponding to the instruments of water and fire. The lower bridge is the celestial river flowing backward, the silver river of the human body, serving the function of bearing the sacred. Above, it connects to the heavenly pass; below, it penetrates the earth’s depths. Stars appear in the sky, tides surge on earth—transformation manifests its forms, while wondrous principle abides within. Emulating heaven and earth, there is nowhere it does not reach.

Rouse the *xun*-wind, move the *kun*-fire, enter the yellow chamber, and complete the supreme treasure. Chen Xiyi said: *"Swiftly the fire-wheel scorches the earth’s axle; suddenly the spirit stirs, emerging from the mountain’s peak. Blow the* xun*-wind, press the* kun*-fire, refine with utmost vigor—only then does lead-gold emerge. Lead ascends with the fire; at that moment, only fire is seen, not the ingredient. The ingredient is within the fire—this is the true yang within* kan*, replenishing the true yin within* li*. The three carts transport it in reverse, ascending to the muddy pellet, pouring into the yellow chamber. Within the divine chamber, the golden embryo is formed, becoming a priceless treasure."*

Water fears drying, fire fears cold; deviate by a hair’s breadth, and the elixir will not form. "Drying" and "cold" refer to excess and deficiency. Nature-water and emotion-fire must be constantly harmonized, striving for perfect balance. The ingredient has degrees of maturity; fire has civil and martial aspects. A hair’s breadth of error prevents elixir formation. It is also said: *"In work, not a hair’s breadth of deviation is permissible—be ever vigilant."* As for the meaning of "deviation": if at any moment one is not true and proper, if the fire does not conform to the method—what should descend ascends, what should ascend descends; water overflows and floods, fire blazes and scorches—the tuning of the zither and lute cannot achieve harmony. There are even greater deviations: if the heart is not refined to death, if spirit scatters and intent dissipates, practice will be without merit. Even if true *qi* is obtained, without the original spirit to govern it, the error is not merely drying or cold—it will surely ruin the endeavor.

Lead-dragon ascends, mercury-tiger descends; drive these two things, do not let them roam free. Fire-dragon is mercury; water-tiger is lead. Here, "lead-dragon" refers to the single point of true yang within *kan*. "Mercury-tiger" refers to the single point of true yin within *li*. The dragon descends from above, the tiger ascends from below. Here, "dragon ascends" means drawing the yang-lead from *kan*, borne upward by the wood-dragon. "Tiger descends" means replenishing the yin-mercury in *li*, following the descent of the metal-tiger. Martial fire draws lead; civil fire adds mercury. Capture the dragon, restrain the tiger, preventing their wildness. Driving these two things is the work of the heart—there must not be a moment when the heart is not gathered, when spirit is not focused. If one is careless, releasing the dragon into the ravine or letting the tiger return to the mountain, the harm will be great. Only when they are long subdued will they obey command and produce the divine ingredient.

chunks.original_text: 《悟真》曰：两手捉来合死斗，化成一块紫金霜。 产在坤，种在干，但至诚，法自然。 《无根树》曰：产在坤方，坤是人。 坤者，干之匹也。 干为鼎，坤为炉，炉产药，鼎炼烹。 干阳，坤阴，阳施阴受顺也。 今乃受坤之施，返而种之于干，岂非逆乎？ 不天地否，而地天泰之见矣。 然此特外形之颠倒，概自阴阳始交，干之真阳入于坤而成坎，坤之真阴入于干而成离，故曰“阳虽女体男儿体，男本阳身女子身”，此为内形之颠倒。 造化之根，动静之始，错综变化，自此起矣。 道之发端，真火逼逐，出坤而过干，此为武火； 野战须防危险，入鼎温烹，但法天地自然，此为文火。 守城端在敬畏，法自然者，我无为而造化自然有为，但至诚无息耳。 盗天地，夺造化，攒五行，会八卦。 斯道窃天地之至精，夺乾坤之造化，效法天地，把握阴阳，攒簇五行，会合八卦，非遇真师，将何法以盗夺之耶。 曰盗，必其不知。 曰夺，必非顺与。 盗夺功成，攒簇不谬。 丹鼎既全，百神会合，土釜封固，日炼时烹，潜符默运，息息归根，换尽阴浊，变为纯阳，即圣躯矣。 水真水，火真火，水火交、汞不老。 曰真则非比象矣，离中一点真液，乃真水也； 坎中一点真阳，乃真火也。 水火分途，何从而得其交哉，此际须仗黄婆勾引，真土擒制。 三昧真火，必从挑拨而炎，与性水合而为一，则离汞之身，可返老而长生矣。 水能流，火能焰，在身中，自可验。 先天之水火，相依为用。 后天之水火，相激成仇。 流下炎上，乃五行自然之性。 当人身中亦有水火，有形可见，有色可睹，神工运火，堪以自验。 岂空谈其理，虚拟其象之可比哉。 是性命，非神气，水乡铅，只一味。 思虑之神，呼吸之气，后天之凡气也。 性是元神，命是元气。 先天之元神元炁，乃为道炁。 若只言神气，则非先天至真之精，至妙之宝，小之乎言性命矣。 铅中含银为白虎，砂中有汞为青龙。 五行顺，则母生子，故曰金生水。 丹道逆。 为儿产母，故曰水生金，此铅出水乡之义。 然铅字至精，说不能尽，即如凡世间之黑铅，亦是感太阴之气，为先天玄水之精，所以能炼外丹。 此乃人身中之铅，铅产于水，而成于火，成仙证圣，只此一味，便是大道之根，阴阳之祖。 人能坎底寻铅，离中得汞，修丹之能事毕矣。 归根窍，复命关，贯尾闾，通泥丸。 人身之空窍有九，关隘有三，自尾闾、夹脊、玉枕，上至泥丸脑顶，此为后上之三关。 藏神于心，藏气于身，则命复而根归矣。 一如草木之收头，效之则必通任督，运河车，金液玉液当知，阴跷阳跷不谬。 穷九关而彻底，升二气于泥丸。 泥丸者，髓海也，补脑之功，精勤无间。 根归命复，不死之道矣。 金浦三车夺圣机，冲开九窍过曹溪，迢迢运入昆仑顶，万道霞光射紫微。 真囊龠，真鼎炉，无中有，有中无。 鼎炉妙用。 非囊龠不为功。 囊者虚器也，妙也。 龠者其管也，窍也。 冬夏二至，一岁之呼吸也。 弦望晦朔，一月之呼吸也。 一日之呼吸在昼夜。 一息之呼吸在延迟。 易曰：“一阖一闭谓之变，往来不穷谓之通”。 性为无中之真有，命为有中之真无。 有无互入，神气始交，神凝气结，斯为圣胎。 托黄婆，媒姹女，轻轻运。

*The Wuzhen Pian* states:
Grasp with both hands and wrestle to the death,
They fuse into a lump of purple-gold frost.
Born in *kun*, sown in *qian*—
Only with utmost sincerity, following nature’s law.

*The Rootless Tree* says:
Born in *kun*, for *kun* is the human.
*Kun* is *qian*’s mate.
*Qian* is the crucible, *kun* the furnace;
The furnace yields the medicine, the crucible refines and cooks.
*Qian* is yang, *kun* is yin—
Yang bestows, yin receives: this is the natural order.
Yet now we receive *kun*’s bestowal,
Only to reverse and sow it in *qian*—is this not perverse?
Not the closure of heaven and earth,
But the revelation of earth-heaven harmony.
Yet this is merely the inversion of outer forms.
From the first mingling of yin and yang,
*Qian*’s true yang enters *kun* to form *kan*,
*Kun*’s true yin enters *qian* to form *li*—
Thus it is said: “Yang though in a woman’s body, yin though in a man’s,
The man’s true form is yang, the woman’s true form is yin.”
This is the inversion of inner forms.
The root of creation, the beginning of movement and stillness,
The interweaving of transformations arises here.
The Dao’s inception: true fire presses and drives,
Emerging from *kun* to pass through *qian*—this is martial fire.
Wild combat demands caution against peril;
Entering the crucible for gentle refinement,
Following heaven and earth’s spontaneity—this is civil fire.
Guarding the city lies in reverence and awe.
To follow nature is to act without acting,
Letting creation move of itself—
Only with unwavering sincerity.
Stealing from heaven and earth, seizing creation’s work,
Gathering the Five Phases, uniting the Eight Trigrams.
This Dao plunders heaven and earth’s purest essence,
Seizes *qian* and *kun*’s creative power,
Emulates heaven and earth,
Grasps yin and yang,
Assembles the Five Phases,
Unites the Eight Trigrams.
Without a true teacher, by what method can one steal and seize it?
To “steal” is to take without the other’s knowledge;
To “seize” is to take by force, not by consent.
When the work of stealing and seizing is complete,
The gathering is without error.
The elixir crucible perfected, the hundred spirits unite,
The earthen cauldron sealed,
Refined by day, cooked by the hour,
Silently aligned, breath by breath returning to the root.
The yin turbidity is exhausted,
Transformed into pure yang—
This is the sacred body.

Water is true water, fire is true fire;
When water and fire merge, mercury never ages.
“True” means it is no mere symbol:
The single drop of true fluid in *li* is true water;
The single spark of true yang in *kan* is true fire.
Water and fire follow separate paths—
How can they merge?
At this juncture, one must rely on the Yellow Dame to broker their union,
True earth to restrain and control.
Samādhi’s true fire must be stoked to blaze,
Uniting with the water of nature to become one—
Then the mercury of *li* may reverse aging and attain longevity.

Water flows, fire flames—
Within the body, this can be verified.
Prenatal water and fire depend on each other for use;
Postnatal water and fire clash as enemies.
Flowing downward, flaming upward—
This is the Five Phases’ natural disposition.
Within the human body, too, water and fire exist,
Visible in form, discernible in color.
The divine work of fire’s circulation can be self-verified—
How could empty talk of principles or imagined symbols compare?

This is *xing* and *ming*, not spirit and qi.
The lead of the watery realm is but one flavor.
The spirit of thought, the qi of breath—
These are postnatal, mundane qi.
*Xing* is the original spirit, *ming* is the original qi.
The original spirit and original qi of the prenatal—
These are the Dao’s qi.
To speak only of spirit and qi
Is to miss the prenatal’s perfect essence,
The most wondrous treasure—
To belittle *xing* and *ming*.

Lead contains silver as the White Tiger,
Cinnabar holds mercury as the Azure Dragon.
In the Five Phases’ natural order, the mother gives birth to the child—
Thus it is said: “Metal gives birth to water.”
In the elixir path, the reverse:
The child gives birth to the mother—
Thus it is said: “Water gives birth to metal.”
This is the meaning of lead emerging from the watery realm.
Yet the word “lead” is most profound—
Words cannot exhaust its meaning.
Even common black lead
Is imbued with the Great Yin’s qi,
The essence of the prenatal mysterious water—
Thus it can refine external elixirs.
This lead within the human body,
Born of water, completed by fire—
To achieve immortality and realize sagehood,
This single flavor is the root of the Great Dao,
The ancestor of yin and yang.
If one can seek lead at *kan*’s base
And obtain mercury in *li*,
The work of elixir refinement is complete.

Return to the root’s aperture, the gate of life’s renewal,
Pierce the *weilu*, ascend through *niguan*.
The human body has nine apertures and three barriers:
From the *weilu*, through the spine and jade pillow,
Up to the *niguan* at the brain’s summit—
These are the three ascending posterior gates.
Conceal spirit in the heart, store qi in the body—
Then life is renewed and the root returns.
Like plants gathering their crowns,
One must activate the *ren* and *du* vessels,
Circulate the river chariot.
Know the golden and jade fluids,
The yin and yang heel vessels must not err.
Penetrate the nine gates to their depths,
Ascend the two qi to *niguan*.
*Niguan* is the sea of marrow—
The work of replenishing the brain demands unceasing diligence.
When the root returns and life is renewed,
This is the way of immortality.

The three chariots of Golden Shore seize the sacred mechanism,
Breaching the nine apertures to cross Caoxi’s stream.
Far and long, they ascend to Kunlun’s summit—
Ten thousand rays of rosy light shine upon the Purple Tenuity.

The true bellows, the true crucible and furnace—
Within nonbeing there is being,
Within being there is nonbeing.
The crucible and furnace’s wondrous use
Cannot succeed without the bellows.
The bellows is the empty vessel—
Its wonder.
The flute is its pipe—
Its aperture.
Winter and summer solstices:
A year’s breath.
New and full moons, dark and crescent:
A month’s breath.
Day and night:
A day’s breath.
Inhalation and exhalation:
A single breath’s extension and delay.
The *Yi* says:
“Opening and closing is called change,
Coming and going without end is called penetration.”
*Xing* is the true being within nonbeing,
*Ming* is the true nonbeing within being.
When being and nonbeing interpenetrate,
Spirit and qi first merge.
Spirit congeals, qi coalesces—
This is the sacred embryo.
Entrusting the Yellow Dame,
The matchmaker for the Alchemical Maiden,
Gently circulate.

chunks.original_text: 默默举。 黄婆者，中央意土，即戊己也。 姹女者，宅中之女。 交会之际，必托黄婆媒合，以通姹女之情。 戊己土中，藏有真火，逼动铅金，火力炽盛，金来归性，入南宫矣。 然后，轻抽默掣，后升前降，下重楼，归丹府，封因而温养之。 陈泥丸曰：“神符默运三关彻，铅赴黄河入大罗。 ” 一日内，十二时，意所到，皆可为。 自子至巳为六阳，自午至亥为六阴。 此言炼一日之道，结一日之丹。 几十二辰中，不必刻定从子起。 但我意欲行便行，勤勤采炼，积累易成。 此是指丹士用功不掇，非指十二时辰须认子也。 饮刀圭，窥天巧，辨朔望，知昏晓。 刀圭，犹言刀头圭角，微末不多之谓。 饮，服也。 《抱朴子》曰：服元气者，亦不多服也。 服之则灵宝在身，天巧自然。 所谓刀圭一入口，白日生羽翰。 月有弦望晦朔，日有朝屯暮蒙。 晦朔为采取之期，屯蒙为运用之候。 识浮沉，明主客，要聚会，莫间隔。 金沉木浮，铅沉银浮。 银何以浮，气也。 性为我之真主，铅从外至，汞自内迎。 饶他为主我为宾，藉彼阳铅运转，收尽一身阴汞。 阴阳配合．常要聚会，勿使间隔，日炼时烹，交媾处，产金莲。 采药时，调火功，受气言，防成凶。 有药有火，无火无药，火从药生，药因火有，《契》曰：“朱雀为火精，执平调胜负。 ”调之使水火均平，无有偏胜。 究竟药是气，火亦是气，受此气者，齐天大福，吉祥止止之事。 防成者，必遭凶祸，指炉残鼎败也。 火候足，莫伤丹，天地灵，造化悭。 周天功成，便当止火。 若持盈未已，无益于盈，必且有损，所以有不知止足必倾危之戒。 何由知其足，盖有止火之景也。 此天地之灵丹，人身之至宝，造化之所吝惜而不轻予者也。 得之者抱玉怀珠，则时刻当护借而不忘矣。 初结胎，看本命，终脱胎，看四正。 未结胎之前，炼精化气。 填平缺陷，谓之筑基。 还丹之后，结为圣胎。 炼气化神，谓之成圣。 初二两关，神注金胎，心攒命蒂。 十月胎圆，瓜熟蒂落，脱胎而出，神透泥丸，气冲天门。 再行乳哺，功满化虚，乘紫雾，驾飞龙矣。 四正者，子午卯酉之宫。 既曰脱胎，则四正之官，无所用之矣，或曰乳哺不用乎。 一朝功满人不知，四面皆成夜光阙。 密密行，句句应。
chunks.translated_text:
Silent ascent.
The Yellow Dame is the central intent-earth, that is, *wu-ji*. The Alchemical Maiden is the woman within the dwelling. At the moment of their union, one must entrust the Yellow Dame as matchmaker to convey the Alchemical Maiden’s longing. Within *wu-ji* earth lies true fire, which compels lead-metal; when the fire’s power blazes, metal returns to its nature and enters the Southern Palace. Then, gently withdraw and silently draw back, ascending behind and descending before, descending the Heavy Tower to return to the Cinnabar Mansion, sealing it to warm and nurture.

Chen Niniang said:
*“The spirit-tally silently moves through the Three Passes,
Lead rushes to the Yellow River and enters the Great Veil.”*

Within a single day, the twelve hours—wherever intent arrives, there one may act. From *zi* to *si* are the six yang; from *wu* to *hai* are the six yin. This speaks of refining the Dao of a single day to congeal the elixir of a single day. Among the twelve branches, one need not rigidly begin at *zi*. Wherever my intent desires to proceed, there I proceed; diligently gathering and refining, accumulation comes easily. This refers to the alchemist’s unceasing effort, not to the twelve hours requiring *zi* as their starting point.

Drink the *daogui*, perceive heaven’s artifice, discern the crescent and full, know dusk and dawn. *Daogui* means the tip of a knife’s edge, a minute and scant measure. *Drink* means to ingest. *The Master Embracing Simplicity* says: “Those who ingest primordial qi do not take much.” Ingesting it, the numinous treasure resides in the body, and heaven’s artifice arises naturally. Thus it is said: “With a single *daogui* in the mouth, white daylight sprouts wings.”

The moon has its crescent, full, waning, and new; the sun has its morning *zhun* and evening *meng*. The waning and new are the time for gathering, *zhun* and *meng* the moment for activation. Recognize floating and sinking, clarify host and guest, ensure union, allow no separation. Metal sinks, wood floats; lead sinks, silver floats. Why does silver float? Because of qi. Nature is the true host within me; lead comes from without, mercury welcomes it from within. Though it be host and I guest, by relying on that yang-lead to revolve, I gather all the body’s yin-mercury. Yin and yang unite—constantly ensure their meeting, allow no separation. Refine daily, simmer hourly; where they mate, a golden lotus is born.

When gathering the medicine, regulate the fire’s work; when receiving qi, guard against calamity. Where there is medicine there is fire; without fire, no medicine. Fire arises from medicine, medicine exists because of fire. *The Canticle* says: *“The Vermilion Bird is the essence of fire,
Holding balance to adjust victory and defeat.”* Adjust so that water and fire are evenly matched, with no partiality. Ultimately, medicine is qi, and fire is also qi. Those who receive this qi gain heaven’s great blessing, an auspiciousness that ceaselessly abides. Those who fail to guard against calamity will suffer misfortune—this refers to a ruined furnace and a broken crucible.

When the fire’s work is complete, do not harm the elixir. Heaven and earth’s numinous treasure, creation’s most grudging gift. Once the Zhou-Tian work is accomplished, cease the fire. To persist in fullness without end brings no benefit to fullness but must cause harm. Thus the warning: those who know not when to stop will surely topple. How to know its completion? There are signs for ceasing the fire. This is heaven and earth’s numinous elixir, the body’s supreme treasure, what creation begrudges and does not lightly bestow. Those who obtain it embrace jade and hold pearls—at every moment they must cherish and not forget.

At the initial congealing of the embryo, observe one’s life-destiny; at the final shedding of the embryo, observe the four cardinals. Before the embryo forms, refine essence into qi, filling all deficiencies—this is called laying the foundation. After the Returned Elixir, the sacred embryo is formed. Refine qi into spirit—this is called attaining sagehood. In the first two passes, spirit infuses the golden embryo, the heart gathers at the life-stem. After ten months, the embryo is complete, the melon ripe, the stem fallen; the embryo sheds, spirit pierces the Mud Pill, qi surges through the Heavenly Gate. Then proceed with nursing, and when the work is complete, transform into emptiness. Mount the purple mist, ride the flying dragon.

The four cardinals are the palaces of *zi*, *wu*, *mao*, and *you*. Once the embryo is shed, the four cardinal palaces are no longer used—some say nursing is also unnecessary. *“When the work is complete one day, none will know;
All four sides become palaces of night-shining jade.”*

chunks.original_text: 仙者，人所爱慕，万万不可得者。 秦皇汉武，天子之尊，求之而不得。 《易》曰：“机事不密则害成。 ”《黄鹤赋》曰：“择善地，慎事之机密。 ”古有明戒，宜敬遵勿妄。 果能慎严密，则自得气得药，还丹温养。 以至于成。 文共八十二句，无一不验矣。 吕祖沁园春注 七（河图，七乃火之成数）返（去而复来，回旋也）还（还其所固有，自先天失落，今乃自外而还于内，自彼而还于我）丹（丹乃乌兔之精结成，故其字象形，配合日月），在人（言不在他物，而专在用人。 《指玄篇》曰：“人须人度超凡世）先须炼己（起手先须炼己，己者我之真土也。 有己必有彼，戊者彼之真土也，合二土而为炼曰圭）待时（待者候也，待其时之来，待其信之至，此时即活子时，时而曰活，非日中之十二辰矣。 时者千金一刻，造化在此，神工在此。 时之义，大矣哉）。 正一阳（天地之冬至，一阳起于九地之下，盖阴极也。 阴极则阳生）初动（此太极一动，人身亦犹是也，自生身以来，第一次初动，谓之元鼎，此一动即是活子时），中宵（中宵半夜也，亥将尽而未尽，子欲来而未来，中间夹缝，界乎亥子之间。 所谓亥子中间得最真是也）漏永（漏永者，工彻昼夜，无时或止也），温温（火气温温也）铅鼎（产铅之鼎，温铅之炉也），光透（此气至，耀金光。 《无根树》曰：“铅鼎温温宝现光”，又曰：“金精旺，耀眼花”，吕祖曰：“铅光发现三日前”，《道情歌》曰：“电光灼处寻真种”）帘帷（帘帷者，闭目内视，有张幕垂帘之象。 透帘帷者，光自外来，真阳之到，有形可睹也），造化（即真阳金精）争驰（交相战也，盖阳欲为主，初至而尚稚，阴欲退去，急切而未能，有如兵民相见也），龙虎交会（龙雌虎雄，不交不成造化。 二物相会，宝体生金），进火工夫（工夫全在进火不差时刻）牛斗危（斗枢也，旋转而指，牛女对待也。 此假三星为言，以明鹊桥上大有危险，教人当刻刻提防，稍一不慎，堕厥前修矣，敬之哉）。 曲江上（曲江水名，喻坎水也。 曰上者，高出于曲江矣），见月华莹净（名丹经皆言亲眼见来，昧者皆揣为自身积贮之金光，再不知月现于西，见之自东，其光华莹净皎洁，亦如太阴一般圆缺。 诸经言月甚多，人不之觉。 《悟真》曰：“月才天际半轮明，早有龙吟虎啸声。 ”天上之月，与人身之龙虎，有何交涉，请一致思），有个乌飞（至无之中，炼出至有。 见金乌飞入广寒阙，太阳移在月明中。 金乌为阳中之真阴，玉免乃阴中之真阳也），当时（犹言当下，即刻也）自饮刀圭（曰自，便非他人。 刀圭，微末也。 自饮者，吸服也。 自饮刀圭，亲尝此药也）。 又谁信（奇事无人肯信），无中养就儿（本来清静虚空之体，从无中生出有来，如妇人怀胎，神攒气结而丹成矣，玄文至此一束）。 辨水源清浊（上文已完，此下再补前说之末备。 天一生水之源是金，清浊即判，金水分形，须要辨之真、审之确，乃为不误大事），木金间隔（东方甲木与西方庚金，相隔甚远。 或因资财间隔，或因人地间隔），不因师指，此事难知（自古至今，圣圣相传，口口相付。 非积思可悟，非猜想可得。
chunks.translated_text:
The immortal is what all people admire yet ten thousand cannot attain. Even the exalted emperors of Qin and Han sought it in vain. The *Book of Changes* states: *“If the mechanism of affairs is not kept secret, harm will arise.”* The *Rhapsody of the Yellow Crane* says: *“Choose a propitious place, guard the secrecy of the affair’s mechanism.”* The ancients left clear warnings—one ought to reverently obey and not act recklessly. If one can be cautious and strictly secretive, then naturally one will obtain qi, obtain the medicine, return the elixir, and nurture it to completion.

The verse comprises eighty-two lines, and not one fails to prove true.

**Commentary on the *Spring in the Qin Garden* by Patriarch Lü (7):**
*Seven* (in the *River Chart*, seven is the completion number of fire), *return* (to depart and come back, to revolve), *elixir* (the elixir is formed from the essence of the crow and hare, hence its character is pictographic, harmonizing with the sun and moon). *Within the person* (it is said to lie not in external things but solely in the person’s cultivation. The *Pointers to the Mysterious* states: *“A person must be delivered by a person to transcend the mundane world.”*) First, one must refine the self (at the outset, one must refine the self. The self is one’s true earth. Where there is a self, there is an other; *wu* is the other’s true earth. Combining the two earths for refinement is called the *gui*). *Await the time* (to await is to watch; wait for the time to arrive, wait for the signal to come. This time is the living *zi* hour—“living” because it is not the fixed twelve branches of the day. Time is a moment worth a thousand pieces of gold; creation and divine work lie herein. The meaning of time is vast indeed).

At the *true first yang* (at the winter solstice of heaven and earth, the first yang stirs beneath the ninefold earth, for yin has reached its extreme. When yin is at its extreme, yang arises), *first stirring* (this is the first movement of the Great Ultimate. The human body is the same: from the moment of birth, the first stirring is called the primordial tripod. This stirring is the living *zi* hour), *midnight* (midnight is the middle of the night, when *hai* is ending but not yet ended, and *zi* is coming but not yet come, a seam between *hai* and *zi*. This is what is meant by “the truest moment between *hai* and *zi*”), *the clepsydra flows long* (the clepsydra flows day and night without cease), *warmly* (the fire’s qi is warm), *the lead tripod* (the tripod that produces lead, the furnace that warms lead), *light pierces* (when this qi arrives, golden light shines. The *Rootless Tree* says: *“The lead tripod warms, the treasure reveals its light,”* and again: *“When the gold essence flourishes, it dazzles the eyes.”* Patriarch Lü says: *“The lead’s light appears three days prior.”* The *Songs of the Daoist Sentiments* says: *“Where the lightning flashes, seek the true seed.”*), *the curtain* (the curtain is the image of closing the eyes and looking inward, like a hanging screen. When light pierces the curtain, it comes from without—the arrival of true yang, visible in form).

*Creation* (that is, true yang and gold essence) *contends in haste* (they engage in mutual struggle. Yang seeks to take the lead, but being newly arrived, it is still tender; yin seeks to retreat but cannot do so immediately, like soldiers and civilians meeting in conflict). *Dragon and tiger unite* (the dragon is female, the tiger male; without their union, creation cannot occur. When the two meet, the precious body generates gold). *Advancing the fire-work* (the work lies entirely in advancing the fire without missing the moment), *the Ox and Dipper perilous* (the Dipper’s pivot rotates and points; the Oxherd and Weaver Girl stand opposite. This borrows the three stars to illustrate the great peril on the Magpie Bridge, teaching one to be vigilant at every moment. A single lapse, and one falls from one’s former cultivation—take heed!).

*Above the Winding River* (the Winding River is a waterway, here likening it to the *kan* water. “Above” means rising high above the Winding River), *the moon’s radiance appears pure* (all elixir classics speak of seeing it with one’s own eyes. The ignorant assume it refers to the golden light accumulated within, unaware that when the moon appears in the west, it is seen from the east—its radiance pure and bright, waxing and waning like the moon itself. Many classics speak of the moon, yet people do not notice. The *Awakening to Reality* says: *“When the moon is but a half-wheel bright at the edge of the sky, / Already the dragon’s roar and tiger’s howl resound.”* What connection is there between the moon in the sky and the dragon and tiger within the person? Ponder this well).

*There is a crow in flight* (from the realm of utter nonbeing, one refines utter being. One sees the golden crow fly into the Moon Palace, the sun shifting into the bright moon. The golden crow is true yin within yang; the jade hare is true yang within yin). *At that moment* (meaning immediately, at once), *one drinks the knife’s tip* (“Oneself” means not another. The *knife’s tip* is the tiniest amount. To drink oneself is to inhale and ingest. To drink the knife’s tip is to personally taste this medicine). *Yet who would believe it* (such a marvelous matter, yet no one is willing to believe), *nurturing a child from nothing* (from the originally pure and empty state, being arises from nonbeing, like a woman conceiving: spirit gathers, qi coalesces, and the elixir forms. The profound text concludes here).

*Discern whether the water’s source is clear or turbid* (the above is complete; what follows supplements what was previously incomplete. The source of the water born from the one in heaven is metal. Clear and turbid are thus distinguished; metal and water take separate forms. One must discern them truly and examine them precisely to avoid great error). *Wood and metal are separated* (eastern *jia* wood and western *geng* metal are far apart, whether by wealth or by distance). *Without a teacher’s guidance, this matter is hard to know* (from ancient times to the present, sages have transmitted it from mouth to mouth. It cannot be grasped by mere contemplation, nor obtained by guesswork).

chunks.original_text: 盖其文深旨远，天地虽大，海宇虽宽，必有继道统之人，但因缘不遇耳。 白玉蟾万里求师，有志者果能效之，虽难知而不难矣）。 道要玄微，天机深远（道之枢要，尽精致微。 天机秘密，深远难露），下手速修犹太迟（今日即起手速修尚觉不早，何也，修短莫测也）。 蓬莱路，仗三千行满，独步云归（海上有蓬莱山，真人仙子所居，成真者德行修逾八百，阴功积满三千，功成行满去朝天，稳驾琼舆凤荤）。 康节邵子诗注 昔真源陈抟以道授洛阳种放，放授汝阳穆修，修授青社李之才，之才授邵尧夫。 尧夫名雍，谥康节，河南人，初学于之才，之才曰：“君非迹简策者，其如物理之学何”既学矣，则又曰：“不有性命之学乎！ ”雍再拜受教。 记称雍智虑绝人，遇事前知，程子谓其内圣外王之学。 图书象数变通之妙，秦汉以来未有知者，独雍得其传。 耳目聪明男子身 耳聪目明，五官周正，较之聋聩，罪福别矣。 天生万物，余得为人，且不为女而为男，亦云幸矣。 英雄志量，湖海胸襟，为圣贤，成仙佛，期无负此七尺之躯而已。 鸿钧赋与不为贫 鸿钧，天也。 天赋之命，人禀之性，无少亏欠； 天能厄我贫贱寿夭之命，不能厄我为圣为贤之心。 赋身之良，万物皆备，岂为贫哉。 因探月窟方知物 探者，采也。 月窟，即下文之姤卦。 物者，即所谓恍惚中有物之物。 方知者，言从前不知，兹因得决归来，依法采取、乃知此物深藏月窟之中。 此物者何物？ 庄周“北溟之鱼”，老子之“有物混成，先天地生”是也。 重阳祖曰：“时至而气自化，静极而机自发”，静定极中，至有动处，即是先天造化，忽有一物，或明或隐，不内不外，此是大药始萌，才有朕兆。 未蹑天根岂识人 蹑，取也。
chunks.translated_text:
The text is profound in meaning and distant in intent. Though heaven and earth are vast and the seas and lands are wide, there must be those who inherit the Daoist lineage—only that their karmic conditions have not yet aligned. Bai Yuchan traveled ten thousand *li* in search of a teacher; if one of resolve truly emulates him, what was once difficult to know becomes no longer difficult.

The essence of the Dao is subtle and mysterious; the celestial mechanism is deep and remote. The crucial pivot of the Dao lies in refining the finest details; the celestial mechanism is secret and profound, difficult to reveal. To begin swift cultivation now is still too late—why? Because the span of cultivation is unfathomable.

The path to Penglai: relying on three thousand deeds fulfilled, one strides alone upon the clouds to return. On the Penglai Mountain amidst the sea dwell the perfected and immortals. Those who attain perfection have cultivated virtue surpassing eight hundred and accumulated hidden merits to three thousand. With merits complete and deeds fulfilled, they ascend to pay homage to heaven, steadily riding the jade chariot and phoenix carriage.

**Annotation on Shao Kangjie’s Poem:**
Formerly, the Perfected Chen Tuan of Zhenyuan transmitted the Dao to Zhong Fang of Luoyang; Fang transmitted it to Mu Xiu of Ruyang; Xiu transmitted it to Li Zhicai of Qingshe; Zhicai transmitted it to Shao Yaofu. Yaofu, named Yong, was posthumously titled Kangjie. A native of Henan, he first studied under Zhicai, who said to him: “You are not one to be confined by written records—how then will you approach the study of the principles of things?” After Yong had learned these, Zhicai further said: “Is there not also the study of nature and destiny?” Yong bowed and received the teaching. Records state that Yong’s wisdom and foresight surpassed others, and he foresaw events before they occurred. Master Cheng called his learning that of “inner sageliness and outer kingliness.” The marvels of the *Tushu* diagrams, symbolic numbers, and their transformations—unknown since the Qin and Han dynasties—were uniquely transmitted to him.

**Ears sharp and eyes bright, a man’s body:**
Ears keen and eyes bright, the five senses well-formed—compared to the deaf and blind, the distinction in fortune and misfortune is clear. Heaven generates the myriad things, and I am born as a human; moreover, not as a woman but as a man—this too is fortunate. With the ambition of a hero and the breadth of lakes and seas in one’s breast, to become a sage, an immortal, or a buddha is merely to avoid squandering this seven-foot frame.

**Heaven’s endowment is not impoverished:**
Hongjun is heaven. The mandate bestowed by heaven, the nature endowed in humans—nothing is lacking. Heaven may constrain my fate in poverty, lowliness, longevity, or early death, but it cannot constrain my heart to become a sage or a worthy. The excellence of the endowed body is complete in all things—how could it be impoverished?

**Only by delving into the moon’s cavern does one know the thing:**
To delve is to gather. The moon’s cavern refers to the *Gou* hexagram below. The *thing* is that which is said to exist within the indistinct and vague. *Only then does one know* means that previously, one did not know; now, having obtained the oral transmission and returned, one gathers it according to the method and thus knows this thing lies deeply hidden within the moon’s cavern. What is this thing? It is Zhuangzi’s “fish of the Northern Darkness” and Laozi’s “something formlessly formed, born before heaven and earth.”

Master Chongyang said: “When the time comes, qi transforms of itself; when stillness reaches its extreme, the mechanism arises of itself.” In the midst of utmost stillness, where there is movement, lies the primordial creation. Suddenly, there appears a thing—now luminous, now concealed—neither inside nor outside. This is the first sprouting of the great elixir, the first sign of its emergence.

**Without treading the root of heaven, how can one know humanity?**
To tread is to grasp.

chunks.original_text: 天根，即下文之复卦。 人者，既杳杳冥冥中之真精，生天、生地、生人、生万物、生仙佛之根也。 言从前未遇师传，不知有此天根，岂能知此蹑之之法，又岂能识此生人之妙乎？ 探月窟而知造化之根源，蹑天根而识生人之所以。 此一联从后溯前，是实证之语。 干遇巽时观月窟 干遇巽，姤也，夏至也。 其象为月窟，一阴起于五阳之下，下弦之象也。 观者，以眼观之，即《阴符经》“观天之道”之观，此观字惟范宜宾《阴符玄解》最为透彻。 地逢雷复见天根 地逢雷，复也，冬至也。 其象为天根，一阳起于五阴之下，上弦之象也。 见者，以眼见之。 所谓天根名，天地之根源，五行之宗祖。 观之有时，见之有处，药产神知，机动籁鸣，时哉不可失。 此一联是法则。 天根月窟闲来往 天根月窟，窍妙是也。 能知此妙，便知此窍。 经曰：“此窍非凡窍，乾坤共合成。 名为神气穴，内有坎离精。 ”来往者，呼吸也。 日往则月来，暑往则寒来； 日月相推而明生，寒暑相推而岁成。 来往于何时？ 子午之候也。 来往于何处？ 卯酉之门也。 经曰：“斗极建四时，八节无不顺。 斗极实兀然，魁杓自移动。 只要两眼缴，上下交相送。 须去静中行，莫向忙里送。 复姤自兹能运用，全丹谁道不成功。 ”此一句是工夫。 三十六宫都是春 经曰：“三十六宫翻卦象，千金不与俗人评。 ”骨节三百六十，毛孔八万三千，无不融和周遍。 又曰：“痒生毛窍，万孔皆春，精神如浴之方起，酥畅如交媾之甜美，日日与君花下醉，更嫌何处不风流。 ”此一句是效验。 同尘按：因见大江东先生与萧先生论及南派丹法，余不识此道，故找来傅金铨先生纯阳祖师五篇注以助解秘探赜。 （若本论坛已有此帖，请斑主删掉本帖） 纯阳祖师五篇注 一、黄鹤赋 奥矣!最上一乘，乃无作而亦无为。 还丹七返，因有动而方有静。 注：道分三乘：初乘、中乘、上乘也。 到最上一乘，无所作为。 从三关逆返，至扑地声离胎，再返至元年之初，此时声臭俱泯，廓然太虚。 一旦露出干元面目，释氏谓之得证实相，于以见初中之必有作为也。 还丹者，丹本我之故物。 还者，自外而还于内，从彼而还于我，去而复返，失而复得之辞也。 七乃火之成数，阳动极而静，阴静极而动，动静相推，互为其根。 炼丹之道，就极静中，寻觅动机。 邵子所谓一动一静之间，天地人之至妙至妙者也。 上德以道全其形，斯纯干之未破； 下德以术延其命，乃撅坎之已成。 注：《道德经》曰； 上德不德，下德不失德。 仙训曰：形以道全，命以术延，必先有接命之术，乃能得有道，以全其形也。 纯干未破，是全体未漏之童身。 倘遇圣师，不须用筑基接命之功，直从十月做起。 然此旷劫难有之事，过此或耗精一次，便是有漏之身。 撅坎已成者，必须行百日炼精化气之功，然后十月三年也。 是以用阴阳之道，即依世法而修。 出世之法，效男女之生，必发天机而作泄天之机。 注：《易》曰：一阴一阳之谓道。 《无根树》曰：离了阴阳道不全。 斯道必匹配阴阳，交接水火。 世人见入山住静，不婚不宦，便谓此是修道。 岂知道在人间，不在山内。 佛云：我于五浊恶世修行，而得大道。 夫修道欲以出世也。
chunks.translated_text:
The "Heavenly Root" refers to the hexagram *Fu* (Return) mentioned below. "Humanity" is the true essence within the profound obscurity—it is the root that gives birth to heaven, earth, humanity, the myriad things, and even immortals and buddhas. Before encountering a teacher’s transmission, one did not know of this Heavenly Root; how then could one grasp the method of treading it, or recognize the wondrous origin of human life? To explore the Moon Cavern is to know the root of creation; to tread the Heavenly Root is to understand the source of human existence. This couplet traces backward from effect to cause—it is the language of realized proof.

**When Qian meets Xun, observe the Moon Cavern**
"Qian meets Xun" is the hexagram *Gou* (Encounter), corresponding to the Summer Solstice. Its image is the Moon Cavern: one yin arises beneath five yangs, the symbol of the waning moon. "Observe" means to perceive with the eyes—this is the same "observation" as in the *Yinfu Jing* ("Observe the Dao of Heaven"). Of all interpretations, Fan Yibin’s *Profound Explanation of the Yinfu Jing* offers the most penetrating insight into this term.

**When Earth meets Thunder, see the Heavenly Root**
"Earth meets Thunder" is the hexagram *Fu* (Return), corresponding to the Winter Solstice. Its image is the Heavenly Root: one yang arises beneath five yins, the symbol of the waxing moon. "See" means to perceive with the eyes. This Heavenly Root is the source of heaven and earth, the ancestor of the Five Phases. There is a time for observing it, a place for seeing it; when the medicine is born, spirit knows it, the mechanism moves, and the flute sounds—such a moment must not be lost. This couplet is the method.

**Heavenly Root and Moon Cavern: idly coming and going**
The Heavenly Root and Moon Cavern are the wondrous aperture. To know this wonder is to know this aperture. As the scripture says: "This aperture is no ordinary aperture; it is formed by the union of Qian and Kun. It is called the Cavern of Spirit and Qi, containing the essence of Kan and Li." "Coming and going" refers to breath. When the sun departs, the moon arrives; when summer departs, winter arrives. The sun and moon alternate to generate light; cold and heat alternate to complete the year. When does this coming and going occur? At the hours of *zi* and *wu*. Where does it occur? At the gates of *mao* and *you*. As the scripture says: "The Dipper establishes the four seasons, and the eight nodes all follow its course. The Dipper itself remains steadfast, while its handle moves of itself. One need only focus the two eyes to exchange above and below. Proceed in stillness—do not rush in haste. Once *Fu* and *Gou* can thus be employed, who would say the elixir cannot be perfected?"

**The thirty-six palaces are all spring**
As the scripture says: "The thirty-six palaces transform like hexagrams—priceless teachings not to be shared with the vulgar." The three hundred and sixty bones, the eighty-four thousand pores—all are harmonized and pervaded. It also says: "When itching arises in the pores, all ten thousand apertures are spring. The spirit is as if freshly bathed, rising with delight; the body is as blissful as the sweetness of union. Day by day, one drinks with the Lord beneath the flowers—where is there anything not refined and free?" This line describes the effect.

**Pure Yang Patriarch’s Five Chapters with Commentary**

**I. The Yellow Crane Rhapsody**
Profound indeed! The supreme vehicle is that of non-action and non-doing. The Reverted Elixir of the Seven Returns arises only when there is movement within stillness.

**Commentary:** The Dao is divided into three vehicles: the initial, the intermediate, and the supreme. At the supreme vehicle, there is nothing to be done. From the Three Passes, one returns in reverse; upon the sound of the falling body, the womb is left behind, and one returns to the beginning of the first year. At this point, sound and scent both vanish, and one merges with the vast emptiness. Once the original face of Qian is revealed, the Buddhists call this "attaining the true suchness." From this, one sees that the initial and intermediate vehicles necessarily involve action.

The "Reverted Elixir" is the elixir that was originally one’s own. "Revert" means returning from without to within, from the other to the self—a phrase denoting loss and recovery. Seven is the complete number of fire; yang moves to its extreme and becomes still, while yin is still to its extreme and becomes active. Movement and stillness alternate, each serving as the root of the other. The path of elixir refinement is to seek the dynamic within the utmost stillness. As Master Shao said: "Between one movement and one stillness lies the supreme wonder of heaven, earth, and humanity."

chunks.original_text: 岂知出世之法，即在此世法中求之。 所谓世法者，君臣、父子、夫妇、兄弟、朋友，日用平常之事也。 人道生男育女，修丹者效之。 三丰祖曰：顺生人，逆生丹。 只一句儿，超了千千万，再休题清静无为枯坐间。 天机者，天根也。 必发天根，乃可透泄此天机也。 方其性命以双修，须仗法财而两用。 注：性无命不立，命无性不全。 始也以性而修命，终焉以命而全性。 始彻终，只是完全此性命二字，必要双修，不可单行。 祖不云乎只修性，不修命，恰似乌金饰顽磬； 只修命，不修性，恰似鉴容无宝镜。 又曰：只修性，不修命，此是修行第一病。 只修祖性不修丹，万劫阴灵难入圣。 萧了真曰：性命双修是的传，冥冥杳杳又玄玄。 世人只解孤修静坐，不悟双修妙理，离了阴阳，背却造化，断无成就。 若欲行双修之事，全仗法财相济。 法财者，法中之财。 两用者，两得其用也。 起手必需，所以有方其须仗之语。 先结同心为辅佐，次觅巨室以良图。 注：钟离祖曰：财不难兮侣却难。 《参同契》曰：两七聚，辅翼人。 莹蟾子曰：辅弼同声不可无，三人同志谨相扶。 天来子曰：要修丹，须结友，同志三人互相守。 若无同志一般人，大药难成金汞走。 《金丹节要》曰：须择同门三友，辅弼相依。 薛道光曰：三人同志谨防危。 《鼎器歌》曰：须用同心三个人。 千经万典，皆曰三人，从未有一人独行者。 觅巨室以良图，谓欲图此事，必依巨室，常言金丹出富豪。 石杏林仙翁授薛紫贤曰：可往通都大邑依有力者为之。 《节要》谓：必依富势一家，以为内助外护。 张紫阳得马都运而后事就，薛道光得张环卫而后丹成。 先结同心，次觅机缘，渐次而求，非历年岁，未可骤得也。 然欲希至道，须密叩玄关。 注：世人欲希图此至真之道，其理精微，其法秘密，不容易闻知，有至玄至妙之机关，当密叩于师，而密印于心也。 择善地慎事之机密，置丹房器皿之相当。 注：善地者，福地也，慎事者，敬慎其事，机密而不敢露也。 丹阳祖曰：择侣择财求福地。 上阳子曰：得侣得财多外护，做仙何必到深山。 有此善地，然后置造丹房，一切器皿动用之物，必须相当。 相当者，对待也。 安炉立鼎譬内外，两个乾坤，炼己筑基，固彼我一身邦国。 注：法财侣地，缺一难成。 四者俱全，然后安炉立鼎。 鼎器法天象地，因而有干炉坤鼎之喻，有内鼎外鼎之称。 《天仙正理》曰：凡言外鼎者，指丹田之形言也； 凡言内鼎者，指丹田中之气言也。 乾坤而曰两个，两个而分内外。 祖有云：两重天地，四个阴阳是也。 鼎器既备，然后行炼己筑基之功。 己不炼，则基不可筑； 筑基不成，是炼己无功也。 古训曰：修仙有程，炼己无限。 《金丹节要》曰：采药容易，炼己最难。 务令性灵神融，心灰意定。 《天仙正理》曰：能合一，则基成； 不能合一，则基不可成。 古人每以邦国喻人之一身，心为君，气为臣，精为民。 精全气足，谓之国富民安。 《悟真篇》曰； 民安国富方求战，战罢方能见圣人。 民安国富，筑基已成也。 一身而分彼我，鼎炉有不内外乎 紧关对境忘情，凭锐气之勇猛； 大抵煨炉铸剑，借金水之柔刚。 注：下手行工，紧要关头，在于对境忘情。

How could one know that the method of transcending the world is sought precisely within the worldly method? What is called the "worldly method" refers to the everyday affairs of ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife, elder and younger brothers, and friends. The human Dao gives birth to sons and raises daughters; those who refine the elixir emulate this. Ancestor Sanfeng said: "Following the course, one gives birth to people; reversing the course, one gives birth to the elixir." This single phrase surpasses thousands upon thousands—no more talk of silent sitting in emptiness and non-action.

The "heavenly mechanism" is the root of heaven. Only by activating this root can one penetrate and release this heavenly mechanism. To cultivate both nature and life, one must rely on both the method and the resources, employing them in tandem.

**Commentary:** Nature cannot stand without life; life is not complete without nature. At first, one cultivates life through nature, and in the end, one perfects nature through life. From beginning to end, it is merely the completion of these two characters—nature and life—which necessarily requires dual cultivation; one cannot practice singly. Did the ancestors not say: "Cultivating only nature and not life is like adorning a dull chime with black gold; cultivating only life and not nature is like a mirror reflecting a face without a precious looking-glass." And again: "Cultivating only nature and not life is the foremost illness in cultivation. Cultivating only the ancestral nature and not the elixir, the yin spirit will struggle to attain sagehood through ten thousand kalpas." Xiao Liaozhen said: "Dual cultivation of nature and life is the true transmission, darkly subtle and profoundly mysterious."

Yet people only understand solitary cultivation in stillness, failing to awaken to the wondrous principle of dual cultivation. Separated from yin and yang, they turn their backs on creation, and thus can never achieve success. If one wishes to practice dual cultivation, one must fully rely on the mutual support of method and resources. "Method and resources" refers to the resources within the method. "Employing them in tandem" means both are utilized to their fullest.

At the outset, this is indispensable—hence the phrase "must rely on." First, one must form a bond of like-mindedness as companions; next, one must seek a powerful household to facilitate the great endeavor.

**Commentary:** Ancestor Zhongli said: "Resources are not difficult to obtain; companions, however, are hard to find." The *Cantong Qi* states: "The two sevens gather, assisting the person." Yingchanzi said: "Aides of the same voice cannot be lacking; three people of shared aspiration must carefully support one another." Tianlaizi said: "To refine the elixir, one must form friendships; three of like mind must guard one another. Without comrades of the same aspiration, the great medicine will be difficult to complete, and the golden mercury will escape." The *Essentials of the Golden Elixir* states: "One must select three companions from the same school to rely upon as aides." Xue Daoguang said: "Three people of shared aspiration must cautiously guard against danger." The *Song of the Cauldron* says: "Three people of one heart are required." Countless scriptures and classics all speak of three people; never has there been one who practiced alone.

"Seeking a powerful household to facilitate the great endeavor" means that to pursue this matter, one must depend on a powerful family—commonly said, "The golden elixir emerges from the wealthy." Immortal Shi Xinglin instructed Xue Zixian: "Go to the great cities and rely on those of influence to accomplish this." The *Essentials* states: "One must depend on a wealthy and influential family for internal support and external protection." Zhang Ziyang succeeded in his endeavor only after obtaining Ma Duyun; Xue Daoguang completed his elixir only after securing Zhang Huanwei.

First, form a bond of like-mindedness; next, seek the opportunity—proceeding gradually, one cannot expect to obtain this hastily without years of effort. Yet if one aspires to the supreme Dao, one must secretly knock upon the mysterious barrier.

**Commentary:** Those who seek this most authentic Dao find its principles subtle and its methods secret, not easily known. There exists a most mysterious and wondrous mechanism; one must secretly inquire of a teacher and secretly imprint it upon the heart. Choose an auspicious location and handle matters with utmost secrecy, arranging the alchemical chamber and vessels appropriately.

**Commentary:** An "auspicious location" is a blessed place; "handling matters with utmost secrecy" means treating the affair with reverence and caution, keeping it confidential without daring to reveal it. Ancestor Danyang said: "Choose companions, choose resources, and seek a blessed place." Shangyangzi said: "With companions, resources, and ample external protection, why must one retreat to deep mountains to become an immortal?"

Having secured such an auspicious location, one then arranges the alchemical chamber and all necessary vessels and implements, which must be appropriate. "Appropriate" means corresponding and fitting. Setting up the furnace and establishing the cauldron is likened to the internal and external, two Qian and Kun, refining the self and laying the foundation to solidify both the self and the nation.

**Commentary:** Without method, resources, companions, or location, success is impossible. Only when all four are complete can one set up the furnace and establish the cauldron. The cauldron and vessel emulate heaven and earth, hence the metaphors of the Qian furnace and Kun cauldron, as well as the internal and external cauldrons. The *Principles of Heavenly Immortals* states: "When speaking of the external cauldron, it refers to the form of the elixir field; when speaking of the internal cauldron, it refers to the qi within the elixir field." Qian and Kun are called "two," and these two are divided into internal and external. The ancestors said: "Two layers of heaven and earth, four yin and yang."

Once the cauldron and vessel are prepared, one then proceeds with the work of refining the self and laying the foundation. If the self is not refined, the foundation cannot be laid; if the foundation is not laid, the refining of the self is without merit. Ancient teachings say: "Cultivating immortality has its process; refining the self has no limit." The *Essentials of the Golden Elixir* states: "Gathering the medicine is easy; refining the self is most difficult." One must ensure that the nature is spiritually harmonious, the heart is ashen, and the intent is settled.

The *Principles of Heavenly Immortals* states: "If one can unite as one, the foundation is laid; if one cannot unite as one, the foundation cannot be laid." The ancients often compared the human body to a nation: the heart as the ruler, qi as the minister, and essence as the people. When essence is complete and qi is abundant, it is called "the nation prosperous and the people at peace." The *Awakening to Reality* says: "Only when the people are at peace and the nation is prosperous does one seek battle; after battle, one can then meet the sage." "The people at peace and the nation prosperous" means the foundation has been laid.

The body is divided into self and other—how could the cauldron and furnace not be internal and external? At the critical juncture of facing circumstances, forget emotion and rely on the courage of keen qi. Generally, in tending the furnace and forging the sword, one borrows the softness and hardness of metal and water.

chunks.original_text: 对境而不染于境，斯真能淡于人情，忘乎物我。 当其下手之际，万念皆空，一心归命，全凭此刚锐勇猛之气，庶乎有济。 《金丹节要》谓：勇猛易就，怠惰难成。 玉液炼己之枢，金水铸剑之要，乃天地之灵根，阴阳之骨骸，得其淬利光茫，始可飞灵走圣。 时当三五，神峰利爽，刚柔应节。 祖云：一口飞灵剑两角，还丹却在峰头落。 煨炉者，温温行火也。 若运用，若抽添，遇险而须当沐浴； 若鼓琴，若敲竹，逢争而便宜守雌。 注：天关在手，地轴由心，枢纽阴阳，斡旋造化，运乾坤阖辟之机，行日月交并之法，抽铅添汞，帘帷光透，铅鼎温温，龙虎会于鹊桥。 斯时大有危险，当退火停符，行沐浴之工。 沐浴者，洗心退藏之谓也。 《金丹真传》曰：竹要敲，琴要鼓。 《一枝花》曰：俺向花丛中，敲竹鼓琴心似水。 《节要》曰：先敲竹以提死，次鼓琴以和音。 《悟真》曰：敲竹唤龟吞紫芝，鼓琴招凤饮刀圭。 敲竹以虚其心，鼓琴以实其腹。 经曰：水善下而不争，是真能守雌者矣。 老子曰：未尝先人，而尝随人。 《悟真》曰：劝君临阵休轻敌。 又曰：饶他为主我为宾。 只此便是不争，对面的干兑，倒转的夫妻，得唱随之义矣。 百日功灵，曲直而能应物。 一年功熟，追摄而已由心。 注：《玉皇心印经》曰：回风混合，百日功灵。 《金丹节要》曰：功成百日，妙夺周天，能曲能直，应物而灵。 一年者，大慨而言之，即十月加卯酉也。 薛道光曰：一年沐浴防危险，十月调和须谨节。 《采金歌》曰：十月功夫要勤咽。 到此胎成果熟，追摄由心。 所谓三百日火，一十月胎，其神离身，忽去忽来，除死录，证仙阶，只待调神出壳。 行三年乳哺、九年面壁之功矣。 能盗彼杀中之生气，以点我阳里之阴精。 注：道者，盗机也。 于极阴中盗取至阳，故《阴符经》曰：其盗机也。 天下莫能见，莫能知。 斯道水火同宫，生杀互用。 生气即在此杀气之中求之。 上阳子谓：有杀人刀子，活人手段。 《悟真篇》曰：若能转此生杀机，反掌之间灾变福。 又曰：若会杀机明反复，始知害里却生恩。 三才相盗，窃天地之机，而长生不死。 夫我乃阳里之阴精。 《悟真》谓：阳里阴精质不刚，独修一物转羸诳。 必须得彼杀中生气以点之。 故曰：但得坎精点离穴，纯干便可摄飞琼。 盗彼点我，如此明白，人何不细思乎 玉液金液，一了性而一了命； 二候四候，半在坎而半在离。 注：玉液了性，金液了命。 《金丹节要》曰：玉液还丹更妙玄，全凭金液炼凡铅。 又因铸剑成栽接，赢得长春寿万年。 又曰：金丹大道，全在神交。 玉液玄机，别无妙术。 一时六候，前二候得药，后四候温养。 所谓二候采牟尼，四候别神功。 半坎半离，非将六候分配坎离。 盖离虚坎实，离为阳中阴，坎为阴中阳。 故曰：取将坎位中心实，点化离宫腹内阴。 始也将无人有，已见龙居虎位； 终焉流戊就己，始知虎会龙宫。 注：《参同契》曰：有无互相入，上有神德居。 无者性也，有者命也。 将无入有，起初入手之功，以性修而命也。 性为青龙，命为白虎，探虎穴，拔虎须，寻虎酥酪，虎穴龙眠矣。 己为阳土，戊为阴土，二土成圭。 《鹤林》曰：流戊作媒将就己，金来归性贺新郎。
chunks.translated_text:
Facing circumstances without being stained by them—this is truly to be indifferent to human sentiment and to forget self and other. At the moment of taking action, all thoughts are emptied, the mind wholly devoted, relying entirely on this keen and courageous qi, and only then may one succeed. *The Essentials of the Golden Elixir* states: "With courage, success comes easily; with laziness, it is difficult to achieve." The pivot of refining the Jade Liquid and tempering the self, the essence of forging the sword with Metal and Water—these are the numinous root of Heaven and Earth, the skeletal frame of yin and yang. Only when sharpened to a gleaming radiance may one soar as a spirit and walk as a sage. At the time of the Three and Five, when the spirit-peak is keen and bright, hardness and softness respond in rhythm. The Ancestor said: "A single flying spirit-sword with two edges—when the Returned Elixir falls, it lands upon the peak’s summit."

To tend the furnace is to apply fire gently and steadily. In its operation—whether drawing or adding—when encountering danger, one must perform the "bathing." Whether plucking the zither or tapping the bamboo, when conflict arises, it is fitting to "guard the feminine." (Note: The Celestial Pass is in hand, the Earthly Axis governed by the heart; the pivot of yin and yang turns the workings of creation, wielding the mechanism of Heaven and Earth’s opening and closing, practicing the method of the sun and moon’s union. Drawing Lead and adding Mercury, the curtain’s light shines through; the Lead Cauldron is warm, and Dragon and Tiger meet at the Magpie Bridge. At this time, great danger arises—one must withdraw the fire, halt the talisman, and perform the work of "bathing." Bathing means washing the heart and withdrawing into concealment.)

*The True Transmission of the Golden Elixir* says: "The bamboo must be tapped, the zither must be plucked." *A Sprig of Flowers* says: "Amidst the blossoms, I tap bamboo and pluck the zither—my heart like still water." *The Essentials* says: "First tap the bamboo to rouse the dead, then pluck the zither to harmonize the sound." *Awakening to Reality* says: "Tap the bamboo to summon the tortoise to swallow the purple mushroom; pluck the zither to call the phoenix to drink the medicinal pellet." Tapping the bamboo empties the heart; plucking the zither fills the belly. The Classic says: "Water excels in flowing downward and does not contend—this is truly to guard the feminine." Laozi said: "Never put oneself first, but always follow others." *Awakening to Reality* says: "I urge you: when facing battle, do not underestimate the enemy." And again: "Let them be the host while I remain the guest." This alone is non-contention. Facing Qian and Dui directly, reversing husband and wife—here one attains the principle of mutual resonance.

With a hundred days of practice, the work becomes numinous, bending and straightening in response to things. With a year of practice, mastery is achieved, and summoning and seizing are at will. (Note: *The Jade Emperor’s Heart-Mirror Classic* says: "When the returning wind blends, a hundred days of practice become numinous." *The Essentials of the Golden Elixir* says: "After a hundred days of accomplishment, marvelously seizing the Zhou Tian, one can bend and straighten, responding to things with numinosity." A year is roughly speaking—ten months plus Mao and You. Xue Daoguang said: "In one year, bathing guards against danger; in ten months, regulation requires careful moderation." *The Song of Gathering Gold* says: "In ten months of effort, one must diligently swallow." At this point, the embryo is formed and the fruit ripens—summoning and seizing are at will. This is what is meant by "three hundred days of fire, ten months of gestation." The spirit leaves the body, coming and going at will, erasing the record of death and attaining the rank of immortality—one awaits only the regulation of the spirit to emerge from the shell. Then follows three years of nursing and nine years of wall-facing.)

One steals the life-qi within that which kills to infuse one’s own yin essence within yang. (Note: The Dao is the mechanism of theft. From the utmost yin, one steals the supreme yang—thus *The Classic of Yin Conformity* says: "This is the mechanism of theft. None in the world can see it, none can know it." In this Dao, water and fire share a palace, and life and death are mutually employed. The life-qi is sought within this killing-qi. Master Shangyang said: "There is a knife that kills, and a hand that gives life." *Awakening to Reality* says: "If one can turn this mechanism of life and death, disaster transforms into fortune in the turn of a palm." And again: "Only when one understands the reversal within the mechanism of killing does one know that harm conceals grace." The Three Powers steal from one another, pilfering the mechanism of Heaven and Earth to attain long life without death. Now, I am the yin essence within yang. *Awakening to Reality* says: "The yin essence within yang is not firm in substance—cultivating this alone leads to emaciation and delusion." One must obtain the life-qi within that which kills to infuse it. Thus it is said: "Only when the Kan’s essence infuses the Li’s cavity does pure Qian enable the capture of flying jade." Stealing from that to infuse this—how clear this is! Why do people not ponder it deeply?)

Jade Liquid and Golden Liquid—one completes nature, the other completes life. The second and fourth periods—half in Kan, half in Li. (Note: Jade Liquid completes nature; Golden Liquid completes life. *The Essentials of the Golden Elixir* says: "The Returned Elixir of Jade Liquid is even more wondrous—it relies entirely on the Golden Liquid to refine ordinary Lead." And again: "Through forging the sword and grafting, one attains eternal spring and longevity for ten thousand years." It also says: "The Great Dao of the Golden Elixir lies entirely in the union of spirits. The mysterious mechanism of Jade Liquid has no other wondrous technique." In one hour, six periods—during the first two, the medicine is obtained; during the latter four, it is nurtured. This is what is meant by "two periods to gather the Pearl, four periods to distinguish the numinous work." Half in Kan, half in Li—this does not mean dividing the six periods between Kan and Li. Rather, Li is empty and Kan is full; Li is yang within yin, and Kan is yin within yang. Thus it is said: "Take the solid center from the Kan position to infuse the yin within the Li palace." At first, bringing non-being into being, one sees the Dragon dwelling in the Tiger’s position. In the end, flowing Wu to approach Ji, one knows the Tiger meeting in the Dragon’s palace.)

(Note: *The Kinship of the Three* says: "Being and non-being mutually enter; above, the numinous virtue resides." Non-being is nature; being is life. Bringing non-being into being is the initial work of taking action—cultivating nature to refine life. Nature is the Azure Dragon; life is the White Tiger. Exploring the Tiger’s den, plucking the Tiger’s whiskers, seeking the Tiger’s marrow—here the Tiger’s den becomes the Dragon’s slumber. Ji is yang earth; Wu is yin earth—these two earths form the Gui. *The Crane Forest* says: "Flowing Wu acts as the matchmaker to approach Ji—Metal returns to nature, celebrating the bridegroom.")

chunks.original_text: 白虎，水中金也； 青龙，火中木也。 木火同宫，金水为侣。 二物中含四象，交会玄宫，而丹结矣。 要知药物之老嫩，在辨水源之清浊。 注：采药真工，端在分别老嫩。 《天仙正理》曰：真工不明，虽采之而无药可采。 药气未至于纯阳，虽知采之，而药不为之采。 盖嫩则气未足，老则气已散，皆不成丹。 夫所谓水源者，天一之生，贵于清洁，不贵污浊，而亦由于一心之静定。 古歌曰：意定神闲水源清，意乱神昏水源浊。 辨之常审，行之要精，不容丝毫盲昧。 炼己待时者，务待阳生于赤县； 遇急临炉者，必须癸动于神州。 注：《泌园春》曰：七返还丹，在人先须炼己等时。 正一阳初动，此其时矣。 待时者，候其时之来也。 赤县，犹云赤水。 赤水玄珠，依时可得。 盖临炉对境，必候真时。 遇急者，令到即行，时不可失。 癸动者，癸生之候。 《悟真》谓“铅遇癸生须急采”是也。 《采金歌》曰：知癸生，晓癸现，三十时辰两日半。 阳生赤县，癸动神州。 求炉置鼎者，可不知乎 若观见龙在田，须猛烹而极煅； 忽闻虎啸出窟，可倒转而逆施。 注：《易》曰：见龙在田，利见大人。 此干之九二爻，正好抽添，须当猛烹极煅。 非若初九潜龙之太嫩，及九三成质，不堪采取也。 《悟真篇》曰：西山白虎正猖狂，东海青龙不可当。 两手捉来令死斗，化成一块紫金霜。 《金丹四百字》曰：龙从东海来，虎向西山起。 两兽战一场，化作天地髓。 颠倒阴阳，逆施造化，吹巽风，鼓橐龠，自太玄关，逆流至天谷穴，金精贯顶，银流滔天，泥丸风生； 绛宫月明，鹊桥瑞香，甘露下降，百脉归元，九关彻底，所谓“乾坤交媾罢，一点落黄庭”。 所谓火逼金行出坤炉，故名七返； 金因火炼归干鼎，号曰九还。 注：金即药也。 《参同契》曰：金来归性初，乃得称还丹。 《指南》曰； 火逼金行，颠倒自然。 《唱道真盲》谓； 人知火克金，而不知金实爱火。 金未出矿离炉，非猛火逼之，无由上升。 所以曰：七返，朱砂反本； 九还，金液还原。 七乃火数，九乃金数。 出坤炉，归干鼎，一施一受，而为返还。 一性一情，而为运用，谓之取坎填离，谓之还精补脑，谓之点离穴，谓之复还干健体，皆此之义。 还者，干所失而复得之物； 返者，我已去而复来之真。 注：先天之乾坤，变而为后天之坎离，是干之中爻，有所失也。 今者取得坎位中心实，点化离宫腹内阴，干之所失，今复还干，我即干也。 自先天混洞之始，失落而去，今者得返我所故有，岂非去而复来乎 殊不知，顺则生人生物，逆者成成仙佛。 注：“殊不知”三字，犹言甚易知也。 老子曰； 吾道甚易知，甚易行； 而天下莫能知，莫能行。 夫天地与我同根，万物与我同体。 人为万物之灵，而与万物并育。 故人物合称。 欲知生仙生佛之理，初不异于生人生物之理，只争顺逆耳。 顺则生凡，逆则成圣，此古训也。 陀阳真人《入火镜》曰：顺则人，逆则丹。 得此理，便成仙。 《无根树》曰：顺为凡，逆为仙，只在中间颠倒颠。 《一笔勾》曰：若知你生身的根由，才晓得造化在手。 张紫阳曰：五行顺兮，常道有生有灭； 五行逆兮，丹鼎常灵常存。 《灵宝毕法》曰：人受凡父母精血之初，溟滓混沌而无形。
chunks.translated_text:
The White Tiger is metal within water; the Azure Dragon is wood within fire. Wood and fire share a palace; metal and water form a pair. These two things contain the Four Images, and when they meet in the Mysterious Palace, the elixir congeals.

To know whether the medicinal substances are old or tender, one must distinguish the clarity or turbidity of the water’s source.

*Annotation:* The true work of gathering the medicine lies precisely in discerning old from tender. *The True Principles of Heavenly Immortality* states: "If the true work is not understood, though one gathers, there is no medicine to be gathered. If the medicinal qi has not yet reached pure yang, though one knows to gather, the medicine will not be gathered. For if tender, the qi is insufficient; if old, the qi has already dispersed—neither can form the elixir."

Now, what is called the water’s source? The birth of Heavenly One values purity and cleanliness, not turbidity, and this also depends on the stillness and stability of the mind. An ancient song says:

*"When the mind is settled and the spirit at ease, the water’s source is clear;
When the mind is scattered and the spirit confused, the water’s source is turbid."*

One must examine this with constant care and practice it with precision, allowing no trace of blindness or ignorance.

For those who refine the self and await the moment, they must wait for yang to arise in the Red County. For those who encounter urgency at the furnace, they must ensure *gui* stirs in the Divine Land.

*Annotation:* *Spring in the Jade Garden* says: "The Seven-Return Elixir requires one first to refine the self and await the time. When the first yang begins to move, this is the moment." To await the time is to wait for its arrival. The Red County is like the Red Water. The Mysterious Pearl of the Red Water can be obtained in due time. Thus, when facing the furnace and confronting the environment, one must await the true moment. For those who encounter urgency, they act immediately upon arrival, for the time must not be lost. *Gui* stirring refers to the moment of *gui*’s arising. *Awakening to Reality* says: "When lead encounters *gui*’s arising, one must gather it swiftly." *The Song of Gathering Gold* says: "Know when *gui* arises, recognize when *gui* appears—thirty *shi chen* in two and a half days. Yang arises in the Red County; *gui* stirs in the Divine Land. How can one who seeks the furnace and sets the tripod not know this?"

If one observes the Dragon appearing in the field, one must fiercely boil and intensely forge. If one suddenly hears the Tiger’s roar issuing from its den, one may invert and reverse the process.

*Annotation:* *The Book of Changes* says: "When the Dragon appears in the field, it is beneficial to meet the great person." This is the second *yao* of *Qian*, the perfect time for withdrawal and addition—one must fiercely boil and intensely forge. It is not like the first *yao*, the Hidden Dragon, which is too tender, nor the third *yao*, which has formed a substance and is unfit for gathering. *Awakening to Reality* says:

*"The White Tiger of the Western Mountains rages wildly,
The Azure Dragon of the Eastern Sea cannot be withstood.
Seize them with both hands and make them fight to the death,
Transforming into a lump of purple gold frost."*

*The Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* says:

*"The Dragon comes from the Eastern Sea,
The Tiger rises from the Western Mountains.
The two beasts battle fiercely,
Transforming into the marrow of heaven and earth."*

Inverting yin and yang, reversing the workings of creation, blowing the *xun* wind, fanning the bellows, from the Great Mysterious Pass, flowing backward to the Heavenly Valley Cavern, golden essence pierces the crown, silver streams surge like the sky, wind stirs in the Mud Pill Palace, the moon shines in the Crimson Palace, auspicious fragrance wafts across the Magpie Bridge, sweet dew descends, the hundred vessels return to the origin, the nine passes are thoroughly opened—this is what is meant by:

*"When the union of Qian and Kun ceases,
A single point falls into the Yellow Court."*

This is also what is meant by: "Fire compels metal to depart the Kun furnace," hence the name Seven Returns; "Metal, refined by fire, returns to the Qian tripod," hence the name Nine Reversions.

*Annotation:* Metal is the medicine. *The Kinship of the Three* says: "When metal returns to its original nature, only then is it called the Returned Elixir." *The Guide* says: "Fire compels metal to move, inverting naturally." *The True Blind of Chanting the Dao* states: "People know that fire overcomes metal, yet do not realize that metal truly loves fire. Before metal leaves the ore and departs the furnace, without fierce fire compelling it, it has no way to ascend." Thus it is said: "Seven Returns: cinnabar reverts to its origin; Nine Reversions: golden liquid returns to its source." Seven is the number of fire; nine is the number of metal. Departing the Kun furnace, returning to the Qian tripod—one gives, one receives, and thus there is returning and reverting. One is nature, one is emotion, and thus there is movement and application. This is called "taking from Kan to fill Li," "returning essence to replenish the brain," "pointing to the Li cavity," "restoring and returning to Qian’s robust body"—all refer to this meaning.

*Returning* refers to the thing that Qian lost and has now regained; *reverting* refers to the true essence that I had departed and has now returned.

*Annotation:* The precelestial Qian and Kun transformed into the postcelestial Kan and Li—this is the middle *yao* of Qian, which has been lost. Now, taking the solid center of the Kan position and using it to transform the yin within the Li palace, what Qian lost is now returned to Qian, and I am Qian. From the primordial chaos of the precelestial, what was lost and gone has now returned to what I originally possessed—is this not what departed and has now come back?

Yet one does not realize that following the natural course produces humans and things, while reversing it completes immortals and buddhas.

*Annotation:* The phrase "yet one does not realize" means "it is very easy to know." Laozi said: "My Dao is very easy to know, very easy to practice; yet the world cannot know it, cannot practice it." Heaven and earth share the same root with me; the myriad things share the same body with me. Humans are the most spiritually endowed of the myriad things and grow together with them—hence humans and things are collectively named. To know the principle of becoming immortals and buddhas is initially no different from the principle of producing humans and things—it is only a matter of following or reversing. Following produces the ordinary; reversing completes the sage—this is an ancient teaching.

Master Tuo Yang’s *Entering the Mirror of Fire* says: "Following produces humans; reversing produces the elixir. Grasping this principle, one becomes an immortal." *The Rootless Tree* says: "Following makes one ordinary; reversing makes one an immortal—it is only a matter of inversion in between." *A Single Stroke* says: "If you know the origin of your own birth, then you will understand that the workings of creation are in your hands." Master Zhang Ziyang said: "When the Five Phases follow, the common Dao has birth and death; when the Five Phases reverse, the elixir tripod is eternally numinous and enduring." *The Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure* says: "When humans receive the essence and blood of their ordinary parents at the beginning, they are turbid and chaotic, without form."

chunks.original_text: 精血既安，一月为胞，二月成胎，三月生魂，四月定魄，五月分五脏，六月开六腑，七月明七窍，八月具八景，九月相足，十月气全，脱胎而生。 还丹之道，大率类此。 方其受灵父圣母妙气之初，必九和十合，而金气始来，亦溟滓混沌，洞灵寥廓，无色无渊之可倚，无形无影之可依，元气镇安，五行敷落，弥罗周回，冥然凝合。 泛啸朗营，复元归空，摄聚郁辅，含孕怀真，生五脏，理五气，合百神，结胎婴，号曰阳神。 虽分彼我，实非闺丹御女之术； 若执一己，岂达鹏鸟图南之机。 注：上文能盗彼杀中之生气，以点我阳里之阴精，已分明彼我矣。 兹复申言之。 虽分彼我，实属正大光明，并非卑污暧昧。 试看天地间，何者非对待之数乎有天便有地，有日便有月，有阴便有阳，有男便有女，有我便有彼。 则凡寒暑昼夜，清浊动静，刚柔夫妇，牝牡雌雄，有独而不配者乎失其理矣。 祖师慈悲度世，恐人错认此理，猜为闺丹食秽，御女采战，此地狱妄人，不知彼我之事者也。 故申言曰：虽有彼我之分，实非此等之事。 《庄子》曰：北溟有鱼，其名为鲲。 鲲之大不知其几千万里也。 化而为鸟，其名为鹏。 鹏之大不知其几千万里也。 是鸟也，海运则将徙于南溟。 以鲲鹏喻道之大，化而为鸟，化气而腾也。 自北而南，由彼至我也。 我为离，为南方朱雀，中含木液青龙； 彼为坎，为北方玄武，中含金精白虎。 祖师垂慈，恐人死执着心肾，在一己身中摸索，便不解庄周图南之文义也。 《一笔勾》曰：只说是命在我身里头，谁晓得一己无有。 此个妙术，此个机关，原有彼我之分，不是一己之事。 坎中一点黑铅，号曰先天，非同类而终不能得； 离里七般朱汞，无真种而片刻难留。 注：《参同契》曰：坎男为日，离女为月； 日以施德，月以舒光。 月受日化，体不亏伤。 坎中一点真阳，是为黑铅。 本玄水之精，先天之真气也。 离中一点水汞，是为朱砂。 本太阳之气，先天之真液也。 《灵宝毕法》曰：天一生水，坎中藏铅； 地二生火，离中产砂。 抱天一之精，而为五精之首者，黑铅也。 铅以生银，铅乃银之母，感太阳之气，而为众石之首者，朱砂也。 砂中生汞，汞乃砂之子。 难得者铅中之银，易失者砂中之汞。 祖师慈悲指点，谓欲觅此一点黑铅，当于同类中求之。 《契》曰：同类易施功，非种难为巧。 又曰：以类附自然，物成易陶冶。 又曰：同类者相从，事乖不成宝。 又曰：雌雄错杂，以类相求。 三丰祖曰：除此同类都是狂。 《节要》曰：但有得同类而易成，乏丹财而不成者。 《无根树》曰：类相同，好用功。 苟非同类，则孤阴不生，断无有得铅之日。 离卦外阳而内阴，即我是也。 七般七窍，所出之津液也。 钟离祖曰：人身内外皆属阴，不知何物是阳精真种者，先天真气，黑铅是也。 汞性飞扬难制。 《契》谓：鬼隐龙匿，莫知所存。 得先天真铅一到，则真汞自留，不复飞扬。 如猫伏鼠，如兔逢鹰，自然而驯矣。 是以假乾坤，立炉鼎，觅太乙所含之真气，赖阴阳作筌蹄，求水府所蕴之玄珠。 注：因乾坤有鼎炉之名，因鼎炉有药物之称。 斯道借假修真，弄假成真。 《百句章》曰：他未知吾道，分明假作真。 借喻乾坤，强名炉鼎。
chunks.translated_text:
When essence and blood settle, in the first month they form the placenta, in the second they become an embryo, in the third the hun-soul is born, in the fourth the po-soul is fixed, in the fifth the five viscera take shape, in the sixth the six bowels open, in the seventh the seven apertures become clear, in the eighth the eightfold vision is complete, in the ninth the limbs are fully formed, and in the tenth the qi is whole—then one emerges from the womb at birth.

The Dao of the Returned Elixir largely follows this pattern. At the moment one receives the wondrous qi of the numinous father and sagely mother, the Nine must harmonize with the Ten before the metallic qi arrives. It too begins in turbid chaos, in a vast and empty expanse—no color or abyss to lean upon, no form or shadow to rely on. The primordial qi settles and stabilizes, the Five Phases scatter and spread, filling the surrounding space, then silently congeal and unite. Roaming freely, it clarifies the spirit; returning to the origin, it merges with emptiness. Gathering and concentrating, it nurtures and embraces the true, giving rise to the five viscera, ordering the five qi, uniting the hundred spirits, and knitting the fetal immortal—this is called the yang spirit.

Though there is a distinction between self and other, this is not the art of chamber elixirs or sexual yoga. If one clings solely to oneself, how can one grasp the mechanism by which the roc charts its course south?

*(Note in original: The above text speaks of stealing the life-qi from within the other’s dissolution to ignite the yin essence within one’s own yang—thus clearly distinguishing self and other. Here, this is further clarified.)*

Though there is a distinction between self and other, this is entirely upright and luminous, not base, impure, or obscure. Consider the world: what is not governed by the principle of duality? Where there is heaven, there is earth; where there is sun, there is moon; where there is yin, there is yang; where there is male, there is female; where there is self, there is other. Then how can cold and heat, day and night, purity and turbidity, movement and stillness, hardness and softness, husband and wife, female and male—how can any exist alone without its counterpart? To deny this is to lose the principle.

The patriarchs, in their compassion to save the world, feared that people would misconstrue this principle as chamber elixirs, filthy practices, or sexual yoga—these are the delusions of hell-bound fools who do not understand the matter of self and other. Thus, they reiterate: though there is a distinction between self and other, this is not that sort of affair.

*Zhuangzi* says: "In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, its name is Kun. The Kun is so vast that no one knows how many thousands of miles it spans. It transforms into a bird, its name is Peng. The Peng is so immense that no one knows how many thousands of miles it spans. When the sea stirs, this bird will migrate to the Southern Darkness." The Kun and Peng are metaphors for the vastness of the Dao—transforming into a bird, it soars on the qi. From north to south, from other to self.

The self is *li* (☲), the Vermilion Bird of the South, containing within it the Wood-fluid Azure Dragon. The other is *kan* (☵), the Dark Warrior of the North, containing within it the Metal-essence White Tiger. The patriarchs, in their compassion, feared that people would rigidly fixate on the kidneys and heart, seeking solely within their own bodies, and thus fail to comprehend Zhuang Zhou’s meaning of "charting the course south."

*The Single Stroke* says: "They say destiny lies within oneself, but who realizes that the self possesses nothing? This wondrous art, this mechanism, originally involves a distinction between self and other—it is not a matter of the self alone."

Within *kan* lies a speck of black lead, called the primordial—without a counterpart of the same kind, it cannot be obtained. Within *li* lie the sevenfold vermilion cinnabar—without the true seed, it cannot be retained for even a moment.

*(Note: The* Cantong Qi *says: "The *kan* man is the sun; the *li* woman is the moon. The sun bestows virtue; the moon unfurls its light. The moon receives the sun’s transformation, and its body remains unharmed." The speck of true yang within *kan* is black lead—it is the essence of the mysterious water, the primordial true qi. The speck of water-mercury within *li* is cinnabar—it is the qi of the great yang, the primordial true fluid.)*

*The Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure* says: "Heaven generates water, and within *kan* lies lead. Earth generates fire, and within *li* arises cinnabar." The black lead, embracing the essence of Heaven’s One, is the chief of the five essences. Lead gives birth to silver, and lead is the mother of silver. The cinnabar, receiving the qi of the great yang, is the chief of all minerals. Cinnabar gives birth to mercury, and mercury is the child of cinnabar. What is hard to obtain is the silver within lead; what is easy to lose is the mercury within cinnabar.

The patriarchs, in their compassion, instructed that to seek this speck of black lead, one must seek it among those of the same kind.

The *Cantong Qi* says:
"Among the same kind, effort is easily applied;
Without the proper seed, skill is in vain."
And:
"Attaching to the same kind follows nature;
Things form easily when smelted."
And:
"Those of the same kind follow one another;
Deviant affairs do not yield treasure."
And:
"Yin and yang intermingle, seeking their kind."

Zhang Sanfeng said: "Apart from this same kind, all is madness."

*The Essentials* says: "Only with the same kind is success easy; without the elixir’s resources, nothing is achieved."

*The Rootless Tree* says: "Of the same kind, good progress is made." Without the same kind, solitary yin does not generate, and there will never be a day when lead is obtained.

The *li* trigram is yang on the outside and yin within—this is the self. The sevenfold seven apertures produce its fluids. Patriarch Zhongli said: "Within the human body, inside and out, all is yin. What is the true seed of yang essence? It is the primordial true qi—black lead." The nature of mercury is volatile and hard to control.

The *Cantong Qi* says: "Ghosts hide, dragons conceal—none know where they reside." But when the primordial true lead arrives, the true mercury naturally stays and no longer flies away. Like a cat pouncing on a mouse, like a rabbit encountering a hawk, it becomes docile of its own accord.

Thus, one borrows heaven and earth to establish the furnace and tripod, seeking the true qi contained within the Great Unity, relying on yin and yang as tools to pursue the mysterious pearl hidden in the watery abode.

*(Note: Because heaven and earth are called the furnace and tripod, the furnace and tripod are given the names of medicinal substances. This Dao borrows the false to cultivate the true, turning the false into the real.)*

*The Hundred Verses* says: "Those who do not know our Dao clearly turn the false into the real." Borrowing the metaphor of heaven and earth, we forcibly name them furnace and tripod.
chunks.overlap_context: Single Stroke* says: "If you know the origin of your own birth, then you will understand that the workings of creation are in your hands." Master Zhang Ziyang said: "When the Five Phases follow, the common Dao has birth and death; when the Five Phases reverse, the elixir tripod is eternally numinous and enduring." *The Complete Methods of the Numinous Treasure* says: "When humans receive the essence and blood of their ordinary parents at the beginning, they are turbid and chaotic, without form."
